commentBody:
WAY too many black squares IMHO. 

And as much as I like a rebus, this one fell flat for me.
What a hoot! This must be some kind of record for rebuses!

Cute. I got the idea quickly and solved in about my normal time.

Never do it again.

That was fun.  Well done, Pablo and Sarah.

And how embarrassing that one of the last words I eventually circled back to turned out to be my own (long ago) alma mater.
so cute! you two rock. thanks for the fresh puzzle!
I caught on pretty fast and then breezed through the puzzle, but it was a good idea and there was a lot of fun solve. Thanks for keeping things fresh.
I hate, hate, HATE rebus puzzles, so this was an epic fail for me.

I went right for the answers that didn't have any shaded squares and worked my way toward the crusts. It's a lovely moment when the concept suddenly clicks. And a very nice visual at the end. And now I have the late night munchies.

So, so much easier than it appears!

Once you get the gimmick it comes together like lightning; all the clues are really easy.

The scary part was the first 3-5 minutes where I was sure they wanted all the black squares to actually represent names of pizza toppings that would complete long megaclues.  Shudder.

But once you grasp and bite the rebus bullet (thank you lower middle) it's really simple and fast.

How to eat the pizza:

Open the box and see the unusual shape.

Frisson of wondering what‚Äôs ahead.

Start in bite by bite. 

After three or six or eight bites, realize most things don‚Äôt fit.

Realize it has to be a stuffed crust!

Stop trying to make the stuffing special. Just do what needs to be done.

Whoa, are those the pepperonis?!

Finish off the enjoyable meal with a dessert of delicious constructor notes.

I detest rebus puzzles, but this one ate the pizza for me. I hated it. It took me about 10 minutes to figure out the answers, which I wrote down on a piece of paper, and then over 30 minutes to figure out how to cram them into the grid. No fun at all.

Now that‚Äôs a spicy Thursday!
I know there will be haters, no worries, everyone likes different toppings, I found this one delicious.
If ypu like rebus puzzles, this was probably fun. I absolutely hate rebus puzzles, and most Thursday gimmicks. I kind of dread Thursday to be honest.

This was actually a very fun puzzle, but my enjoyment was hampered by scrolling through tons of clues early that I knew the answer to, but didn't fit. Honestly this would have been a 10/10 if the reveal happened up front, instead of after letting me get mad about "ugh another rebus" for 20 clues. Good puzzle that could have been great if the reveal wasn't so late.
Keying it in on my cellphone was an epic pain but it was fun to see the graphic at the end. Yum.

I am seriously missing something here.  I got it done, but it still makes no sense.  What are those grayed edges supposed to do?  

Thank you!
I like rebuses; it took me a few minutes to realize that every edge piece had one. STUFFED CRUST was a big help, as was the shading.
It‚Äôs rebus hell. Looking forward to Friday.

19A and 15D was the toehold, after things were looking bleak for the first minute (had to be in the middle!). Once I hit the revealers, my confusion made sense, and then the really important part was to remember which key on my laptop ("Insert", but not "Ins" on the numeric keypad) goes straight to rebus mode so that I didn't have to keep scrolling and mouse clicking. At that point it was straightforward, but I was pretty impressed that they managed to pull this off. A relatively easy puzzle once you caught on to the trick, but still, Kudos!
Not a crossword. Just a puzzle. Phooey!

At first I was completely confused.  I began with a couple of 'cheats', so puzzled that the answers given were longer than the available squares.  Then I realized, rebuses!  A brief glance at the answer pdf, and a recognition.  After that, filling wasn't so bad.  And yes, I had less cheats on this puzzle than on the previous puzzle.   It is a gluten free pizza, so I won't complain!  (I love the pizzas with the cauliflower crust, btw.  Greek pizza on cauliflower crust, YUM!)

I'm not mad per say and I don't think this was a totally unmerited idea, but I've never seen a puzzle like this before,  I had no way of knowing I had to read every question, I didn't even know their was a "comments" feature for these puzzles until just now, I like to play alone and without spoiling anything. I love solving problems but the point of a crossword is to operate a game with standardized rules making it solvable.  If you're going to change the rules like this you should at least make it obvious in a way that people who are unfamiliar with the concept or change will understand.  Any kind of actual note "abnormal puzzle" would have been enough to make this far less confusing.  And for the record I noticed the color change immediately but having never seen a puzzle like this before I thought it was just and attempt to make a cute pizza graphic to relate to some of the answers, not that it was going to be a full rewrite of how crosswords work.

This is my favorite kind of Thursday puzzle! Challenging but the clues aren‚Äôt esoteric - it starts to come together and then once you understand the gambit, it gets more fun! 

If you don‚Äôt know about rebus solves, then this puzzle would be super annoying‚Ä¶ BUT this is the perfect puzzle to gain mastery over them. 

And amazing structure and reveal, too! üëèüèªüëèüèªüëèüèª
This was a most enjoyable puzzle with multiple rebuses all around the edges. Once you got the hang of it it was almost intuitive to complete the puzzle.

Thursday puzzles are my favorite, especially with a fun theme like this one. CARELL was a dead giveaway that the edges were rebuses, especially when I knew ALPACA but was stumped by only having 3 squares. 

Bonus points for the double rainbow reference in the constructors notes. A great chuckle before bedtime!

I‚Äôm no big fan of so many rebuses and needing to get halfway through the clues before any reveal was tedious. But the real crime of this puzzle are the blinding white corners when viewing the grid in dark mode. This was among my least favorite puzzles ever.

First the article "Pizza in America is Better Than Ever" that appeared in the Times yesterday or the day before, and now this: I'm getting the idea that there is a certain, er, piety toward pizza at the Times. As if some focus group came back with, "People seem to want more disheartening polls about Biden -- and pizza related stuff." It's clear that the powers-that-be at the Times are not made men from the Sicilian mob, otherwise the grid would be square. If you get my drift. It's pretty freakin' virtuoso, not only the rebus crust but then having the two revealers AND the toppings (and what are those two green pairs - sprigs of parsley? basil?), well, √® semplicemente incredibilmente sorprendente. I also like the mini Hispanic theme -- castillo, abuela, Suarez, alpacas (native, like spectacled bears, to the Andes), the Pinta -- which goes with the theme of the pizza article, that the best pizzas often mix cuisines and cultures to great effect. Or to horrible effect: I'm lookin' at you pineapple-anchovy-Canadian bacon! 'Bout time I start heading to the kitchen. I got dibs on that last slice of taro-lilac-seacrab, don't even think about it! https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/25/dining/pizza-america.html

Honest question for Deb:

Do you ever not like a puzzle? I love, love, LOVE your positivity and share a lot of your columns with friends in hopes of encouraging them to try puzzles later in the week.l. I also notice that the vast majority of your columns seem to point out how great a constructor has done.

I hate rebuses - rebi? Rebusi? 

40 of them is torture. 

This was a cryptogram, and I know many will love this.   

It feels like homework.  I hate homework. 

You won today.
Great puzzle, great column, great constructor notes. I had fun and cracked up at stuffed crust. Thanks!

I get that a lot of people like Thursday tricks but what‚Äôs most frustrating is that thursday would be a great day for a regular crossword in terms of difficulty (challenging but not too time consuming). I wish they would have regular one and maybe add a rebus one as a separate thing with the minis or something. Anything but this.
For people who don‚Äôt like rebuses: why don‚Äôt you just skip Thursday?
Clever design & fill. Both @Deb‚Äôs & constructor notes were vital for me to solve. Most rebuses in a puzzle? Now my finger is tired & I‚Äôm craving pizza!
Doing this on a laptop was just an exercise in tedium with the page constantly shifting.  I cannot adequately express how much I hated this.

I was completely lost after the first pass-through and, contrary to my personal rule, looked at this commentary. Once I saw the trick about rebuses around the edge I was able to fill it in with relatively little trouble. Please don‚Äôt do this again.
This puzzle was delightful. Thanks to the constructors!
Delicious solve! Compliments to the chef!

I predict a lot of complaints from pizza lovers and rebus haters alike. 

My first rebus discovery was AL-PA-CA, and I thought we were in for some American geography. rather than Italian gastronomy. 

Did anyone else see SLED(D)ED descending into REINDEER?

I liked the theme and appreciate the work it must have taken to get all the rebus entries to work both down and across.

Once it became apparent that all of the edge spaces had two letters, the answers were all pretty easy. No tricky clues, misdirection, unknown trivia, etc.

Probably would have been close to a Thursday PB except for having to type in all the rebus answers on my phone which gets a little tedious. 

Not often I wish for the old days of pencil and paper, but today I did!
This was a cute idea, pretty fun to solve, and I am not necessarily against rebus puzzles but the stuffed crust just looks too ugly I‚Äôm sorry‚Ä¶

Loved it ‚Äì
the unicorn of puzzles!

I lucked out by starting in the SE, where Duane REA-DE and Oscar MAY-ER, followed by RE-IN-DE-ER brought it all to light, and gave me a whoosh of adrenaline. The party had just started!

With so many entries scratching the rebus itch, I appreciated that the fill was quite easy, creating a wonderful balance in the puzzle.

A great big toast ‚Äì with pizza, of course ‚Äì to the two of you, Paolo and Sarah, extensive to the graphics team.
Bravo!
From the comments it seems like there was a visual aspect that didn‚Äôt show up on my iPad. Were toppings supposed to appear?

I‚Äôm very surprised by all the comments about hating this puzzle.  I thought it was a quintessential puzzle for a Thursday- which is traditionally ‚Äúgimmicky‚Äù for those whining about how this isn‚Äôt a crossword.  It‚Äôs easy enough to skip Thursdays if you don‚Äôt like this style!  Personally, Thursdays are my favorite puzzle of the week.

NYT crosswords follow a very set pattern. 

Mondays are easiest, with progressively harder puzzles on Tuesday and Wednesday.  

Thursday is ‚Äúgimmicky‚Äù or ‚Äútricky‚Äù.  

Friday is harder than Wednesday.   

Saturdays are hardest. 

Sundays are larger grids and have a title, which is themed to the puzzle.   

Well done to the creators!  This is extremely clever and excellently constructed!

I will never understand the users who write in on a Thursday about how they hate rebuses and other deviations from crossword conventions. I‚Äôm begging you - just don‚Äôt do the Thursday puzzle. If the menu says anchovies galore, please don‚Äôt complain about how fishy your slice turns out to be.

For the record, I thought this was one of the more clever and enjoyable Thursdays in a while, and after the ‚Äúaha‚Äù moment the solve was straightforward. A little slower than my average, but worth it for the reveal. Thanks for a great puzzle!

Super fun puzzle and I *loved* the constructor notes. So fun to see the thought process presented in such a clever way. 

I would greedily read the text thread behind every collaborative puzzle.

So many people are complaining, but it feels more like 'complaining about rebuses just because they don't like rebuses' than about the puzzle itself. 

In my case, I found this delightful! Solving it was like eating a pizza - having to slice it up, starting from the inside, and working out towards the crust. The construction is really fantastic, and I'm impressed at how it managed to pack so much into such a small puzzle footprint. One of my favourite crosswords in a while, and unless Sat or Sun are amazing, a solid contender for puzzle of the week. I love the final look of it too, with all the colours!
Well done!  (Not how I like my pizza, but my crosswords)

Judging by the comments, it seems like this was a lot of folks‚Äô first introduction to rebus puzzles. Which is surprising to me: I only started solving in January, and feel like the ‚ÄúThursday is often a rebus‚Äù concept was drilled into my head a dozen times at this point.

Anyway, welcome everyone! If you hate rebuses, you‚Äôre in good company on the comments thread. But aside from the volume and predictability of their locations, there‚Äôs nothing new about this puzzle from a gameplay standpoint. Don‚Äôt take it out on the constructor!

Signed,
Someone who was wildly confused on his first Thursday solve, and didn‚Äôt even know the word ‚Äúrebus‚Äù until he read the angry comments section.

Absolutely loved this puzzle. Shaded area and obvious answers like ALPACA, ABUELA, and CARELL gave it away. Didn‚Äôt totally get the edges until DAS and SORKIN though. Personally I found it significantly easier than normal Thursday rebus puzzles where it‚Äôs harder to know where exactly the rebus will show up. 

Stumped me for a while on MUDSTAIN and MURALIST though so a longer time for Thursdays. 

Also entering rebus is pretty easy on mobile (and even easier on desktop). I don‚Äôt get what the fuss is about.

I‚Äôm far from an accomplished solver, so I was thrilled when I finished without resorting to the Wordplay column.  (I did have a few look-ups, though.) 

And I think this was a very clever puzzle!!!
Very nice! It‚Äôs just about lunchtime in Manila as I finish, heading out to the nearest Sbarro now.

I‚Äôm new to enjoying crosswords but this one made zero sense to me. I gave up and revealed the puzzle. Would have been nice to know that was the intent. I thought the puzzle was glitched or broke ‚Ä¶.
I did not like this puzzle at all, i didn't even bother to finish it
This was so fun!! The most fun I've had solving the crossword in ages!
This puzzle was just one big gimmick just like its theme, stuffed crust pizza. Too much of a not very good thing.
This puzzle sucks. I don't know why anyone thinks rebus is fun. It's just lazy and ceases to be a crossword.
O boy! A cutesy rebus. Hopefully, tomorrow there will be a crossword puzzle (since that's what I pay for).

This puzzle gave me a lot of joy. Fun, slightly different-than-usual challenge. The fill was at exactly the right level of difficulty to make it possible to figure out the trick, and while it took me a bit longer than a usual Thursday, I thought it was fun and well done.

A really fun brain tingler once I got the trick! Definitely had to make use of the Wordplay explanation, but only so far as the revealer hints and not the tricky clues. A few of these were thinker clues where the usual word was NOT the answer, which a nice change of pace. PS. Very much agree‚Äîthe best constructor‚Äôs note and photo, EVER.
Loved this deliciously baked puzzle. Wednesday fill with Thursday spice. Last to fall was LIRA/?maRk

There has to be a less annoying way to enter the rebuses than how I am doing it. I go click on rebus, enter the two letters, then hit the ‚Äúnext‚Äù arrow and then the ‚Äúlast‚Äù arrow so I can fill in the rest of that clue. Help? I wouldn‚Äôt have minded this so much if filling it in wasn‚Äôt so tedious.
Please don't do this again.  This was an exercise in tedium where more time was spent on the mechanics of creating rebuses than actually solving rather simple clues.
I disliked this puzzle, it was pointlessly confusing.
Went quickly once I realized all the perimeter gray squares were rebuses. Their clues were relatively easy.
I don‚Äôt know if I was just in a mood or what‚Ä¶ but this puzzle was not my jam. Got annoyed a third of the way through and just picked up a book.

I'm sure the haters gonna hate this one, but I loved it! The incorrect answer of CASa for 1A tricked me for a good long time and thwarted my attempts to decipher the rebus pattern. Once that was fixed things fell into place nicely. 

This was my kinda Thursday puzzle!
I hated this one. Please no more rebus. I pay for good crosswords and rebus is hard, confusing and annoying. It makes me want to cancel my subscription. No more rebus.

I solved the ENTIRE puzzle (with autocheck, because I don‚Äôt have the patience to be wrong) before I remembered that rebuses are a thing. I only recently started using the NYT Games app, which hides the rebus option behind a ‚Äúmore‚Äù button on the keyboard. Out of sight, out of mind, even on Thursdays. I was trying to keep track all the missing letters in my head while wondering things like ‚ÄúHow the heck does KETB mean ‚Äòclosely monitor‚Äô?‚Äù Only after I finished (just a couple minutes slower than my average) did I come read this column and figure out the trick. Of course, then I had to clear it out and complete it properly. 
Quirky, but this was not my favorite.

Wow! A hundred comments by midnight! I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if we break 1000 today!

Most of them are from haters, and things like ‚Äúthis isn‚Äôt a crossword‚Äù that tell me there are a lot of newbies out there. Imagine stepping into, and then out of the batter‚Äôs box after three quick strikes, and complaining, ‚ÄúNo fair, curve balls.  I didn‚Äôt know that could happen.‚Äù

Without curve balls, hitting would be too easy and the games would be five hours long and the final scores would be 48-27. 

Curve balls make baseball a better game. As a batter, you have to be able to figure out when to expect them, and how to hit them.

Or give up and sell cars for a living. 

This puzzle was a masterpiece, and you do it a disservice by blaming the puzzle for the fact you weren‚Äôt ready for it. (Yeah, I know, you‚Äôre the exception: you‚Äôve been solving for 15 years and you still hate it, blah blah, blah.)

This one could be a contender for Puzzle of the Year. 

A perfect game is a work of art, but the opposing batters on the losing team still don‚Äôt like it.

It took me longer than it should‚Äôve to realize that the shaded squares were all rebuses. When some obvious answers didn‚Äôt fit ([CA]RELL especially), I moved to the middle and put in gimmes like IPO, TORI and URDU. Once I figured out the trick, I filled in the rest of the grid as quickly as one can given the extra keystrokes that the rebuses require. I‚Äôm confident that I put two letters in every rebus square, but the REINDEER of my finished puzzle says RIDER.

Clever concept! Thanks, Mr. Pasco and Ms Sinclair!
The puzzle actually made me gasp when I opened it, a real jumpscare lol. Once I got the rebus, it was a breeze! Good job, guys!
Please count me among the lovers of this fun puzzle!
I'm not a rebus fan but have to give major kudos for the creative idea and execution. It's obvious the puzzle creators really enjoy what they do!
Straight to crossword editor jail.

Although there have been rebus puzzles that have caused me to quit in frustration, I don't hate them- especially now that I consider myself a seasoned solver and know to look for them on Thursday. I thought this one was a nice and easy way for folks to learn how to solve them- Tuesday difficulty with Thursday construction; there are A LOT of entry points with common answers that clearly indicate there is a trick to be sussed out:

Sister Act Star
Jazz's James
Steve of The Office
King of the Faries
Spanish Grandmother

If you're new to this: welcome to rebuses! They can be very challenging but very rewarding, and they show up fairly regularly on Thursdays. 

The haters gonna hate.

Whatever- I really enjoyed this one!

I know there's a few haters of rebus crosswords, but I liked this one...although not at first. It was a bit daunting to get a foothold in, with the majority of across answers requiring a rebus filling. 26A and 41A made it pretty clear, and then it was smooth sailing from there.
Perfect timing for my time zone too, as TUE-SAT puzzles drop at midday for me.

Oh this was SO GOOD. i hated it for about 5 minutes until I figured out the trick, then I was mad at how good it was. Finished 25% below my average time for a Thursday. It was a perfect balance of straightforward and tricky clues to enable the recognition of a rebus without sacrificing the challenge. 

*chef‚Äôs kiss!*
Ok, that is probably the most memorable puzzle of the last five years. Ingenious and fiendish.  We will refer back to this one for years to come. What a clever idea!

This was supreme, by the looks of it. A delicious solve, any way you slice it!


Word of advice to the reader who loved this deep dish: stop here unless you don‚Äôt mind the extra crust.


cc: emu handler
I loved this puzzle. Not having the full benefit of the crossings to help out with many of the clues broke my brain in the best possible way. THIS is why I do these puzzles!
This puzzle was not the least bit fun for me. Sorry.

I got the gold square and finished in 25 minutes, but boy was that tough. ERIN/STINKY tripped me, was convinced it was ERIc/STIcKY, as in a sticky situation. Had a few other mistakes I found on my proofread. Loved the theme, though, and this has to be a record for rebuses (rebusi?)
Once you catch onto the gimmick it does make sense, but once you get it, it's not much of a challenge any more. Oh well, the occasional rebus is OK, I guess.
Well that was thoroughly unenjoyable. I do like the occasional rebus, but really? Kind of a mess of a puzzle. Not a big fan of stuffed crust either.

Always fun to chew on (pun intended) something new in a Thursday crossword! Not every gimmick has to be to every solver‚Äôs taste (there we go again), but count me a fan of this one. The colorful graphic on the app version is an added delight.

Pretty fun puzzle but relatively easy once you figure out the gimmick.
My only regret is that no toppings made it into the puzzle itself.
Anyone know what the ‚Äúmythical Perfectly Scored Wordlist‚Äù from the Constructor Notes is referring to? cc: emus
A fun puzzle whose trick quickly revealed itself.  The only clue I really didn‚Äôt like was 58D, which seems so regional as to be obscure even for a Thursday.

I really liked the idea of this puzzle. The color at the end was fun.
I just wish it weren't so annoying to enter rebuses in the app. It really breaks up the flow of solving, and having so many like in this puzzle really exacerbated that.

i found this enjoyable as a former rebus hater. At first i thought the black squares represented something underneath, but with a good combination of Tuesday level clueing and the revealer, it was easy enough to figure out the rebuses. I did not finish though as MURALIST crossing STUCCOS and REINDEER crossing 3 trivia names was too hard for me. Cool idea tho, i LIKED this one. For the rebus haters, just skip this one and do a Monday and Tuesday archive, we all know to half-expect rebuses on Thursday
I usually like rebuses but this was too much. I felt the way I do about voting- I did it but I didn't enjoy it.

I love puzzles like this, where you have a clue about where the rebus answers go. Hate the other ones. 

Good puzzle!

1. Rebuses are sooooooo tedious if you play via the app (as I do). Having to toggle between keyboards is a drag and disrupts the solve flow. This puzzle was nearly all rebuses, which made for way too much time inputting.

2. I was disappointed that there wasn‚Äôt more of a twist to the theme than all the periphery squares doubling up. I was expecting the letters to spell out something or some other clever twist. The cluing was pretty easy for a Thursday once I cracked the theme, so my biggest takeaway was the tedium of all that rebus toggling without much of a challenge. Verdict: More hassle than fun.

What a great puzzle!  I was thrilled when I finished and was gifted with the visual surprise along with the winner winner tune.  It took me forever to find my typo after correcting leaking/stinking realizing the edges were all 2 letter rebuses. I had CAR in my CA rebus for Carell.  Bad on me. I'd miss my nose if it wasn't so close. 

My first impression was "whoa Nelly" ! But pizza just isn't mean enough to be scary. So accepted the challenge and game on!  Loved doing it! Thank you NYT, and for the genius constructors Pasco and Sinclair! Loved your mustachios.

Delicious puzzle!

The southwest "corner" nearly

prevented gold star

I also hate, hate, hate.....  STUFFED CRUST pizza!! 

But I love, love, love this puzzle!! 

What fun!! I grinned from ear to ear the whole way through!!

My first inkling was at ALPACA, my second inkling was at Steve from the office... but I wasn't totally sure how to spell his name or if there was another Steve from the office. 

Believe it or not, the Nancy Drew clue 100% clinched it for me... rebus!! My misspent youth up in a treehouse or in my cozy pink bedroom reading Nancy Drew and Trixie Belden mysteries really have paid off! Huzzah!!

And once I figured out from the STUFFED CRUST that that's where all the rebuses were, I ended up sailing through at way better than average time, with a few little sticky, but manageable, spots. 

Even though there were a lot, I feel like this is a very accessible puzzle for newer people to get their feet wet, and I hope that they can stick to it. 

I'm still very much a new person at under a year, so I get if it's your first time encountering a rebus... it's very confusing. My first time encountering one, I didn't know it was a possibility or how to do it, so I do get that, but I still think it's a very approachable one because you can see where the rebuses are and the clues were all very accessible. 

While I'm not a fan of a STUFFED CRUST on my pizza, I am a big fan of garlic butter around the edges of the crust! Mmm!!  And when I make homemade pizza, I always add garlic into the dough. Never know when those vampires are out there!

Bravi Sarah and Paolo.  Quite the masterpiece you constructed.  
And I also enjoyed your constructors' notes.
This was so much fun!

I had a feeling the drama department would weigh in on this one and sure enough they did not hold back. Sigh.

As for me: Loved the puzzle, loved the column, loved the constructor notes, LOVED the photo of Paulo and Sarah, and loved the surprise ending! 

Maybe not the hardest Thursday but definitely one of the most fun and clever puzzles of 2024.

I don't understand the unicorn clue... would someone please fill me in?
Does IPO have more than one meaning?

My wife will HATE this! I loved it! Very quick for a Thursday, even using the app. Congratulations to the constructor! If the cluing had been a little more challenging it might have been an epic Thursday quagmire instead of 10 mins faster than average.

This puzzle was BRILLIANT!  And FUN FUN FUN!  I absolutely loved it.  I also loved the constructor notes and the transformation from black and white puzzle to colorful pizza puzzle.  Absolutely brilliant!
Strands and the Crossword, both clever, both yummy.

I‚Äôve been doing these for a few years. 

I‚Äôm afraid to ask but-  what‚Äôs an ‚Äúemu‚Äù in the comments?!?!

(I‚Äôve googled, but only get examples of emu responses in crosswords)

Thanks
I needed a little help (thanks, community) but I made it ! Thank you Sarah and Paolo for this challenging, fun, and satisfying puzzle !

The rebuses worked with autocheck ths time except for the last one I needed to do. I had only one correct letter in that square intending to go back to it. But the puzzle congratulated me for finishing when I added the correct letter to another square. And of course once the puzzle was marked as complete I couldn't add the final letter to the rebus.

Okay I can't hold back any longer, so many posts have been about, "oh a Rebus!? Can't wait to read the hate posts" (sarcasm).  But after reading these comments for a while, I don't think it's the negativity that's a problem here.  I'm worried the sheer volume of pizza jokes, I fear we've oopened Pandora's flimsy, greasy, cardboard box.üßê
Having just spent the day in Naples yesterday where I had nothing but pizza, I was very happy to see this crossword. The pizza gods have smiled upon me üçï

I don‚Äôt know which was more fun, solving this deliciously wicked puzzle, or anticipating all the anti-rebus grousing in the comments. (Seriously, people‚Äî rebuses exist.  Learn to live with them or just skip Thursdays.)

My only regret is a lack of auto-updating that caused me to miss the fun surprise at the end of the puzzle, It was like making a great pizza then realizing I‚Äôm out of red wine. Still tasty, but lacking the perfect chaser.
Lovely puzzle but Oh! The Calories!
Really cool idea! I enjoyed the multitude of rebuses, especially the requisite reference to Peru - ALPACA
Agree about the fun, but with so many rebuses (rebi?) I wish the ‚Äúrebus‚Äù button was on the first/main screen keyboard of the iOS app. All that clicking made me hungry!

This was loads of fun to solve on my commute into Canary Wharf this morning, while a bit tricky I thought it was accessible to experienced solvers given some relatively easy clues pointing to the rebus element, e.g. even if you don't know right away you could look up the first name of a Marvel hero shared by 3 actors. Bravo to the constructors for their delicious and creative puzzle!

5 minutes in, my head was in my hands and I was groaning "Oh my gooooooood."
I hated this one more with every additional red slash.
Please do more just like it.

Always entertaining when something out of the ordinary pops up. 

This one I could see and even appreciate so was in the I ‚Äúenjoyed this‚Äù camp but equally this time last week was less than happy so it‚Äôs swings and roundabouts. 
 
The levels of irritation and ‚Äúhaters gonna hate‚Äù commentary seems about on par so think the setters and editors and emus will not be too stressed. 

Just happy to be moving through the week without hitting the wall.

Wow, just wow! What a fun puzzle! The clues weren't too difficult so I realized early on that almost every entry was one letter too long so the shaded squares must be rebuses. Puzzle construction software runs off wordlists, which are usually bundled with the software or acquired separately (you can buy them, but there are also  free ones). 

Each word is scored by whoever created the wordlist, but the constructor can adjust that. The higher the score, the more likely it is that the software will offer a word as potential fill. Most software lets you set a minimum score, so words the constructor doesn‚Äôt like may never be considered as possibilities. 

I suppose the ‚Äúmythical‚Äù reference is that no wordlist is ever perfectly scored. Even if the constructor has thought about every word on the list, another constructor or a solver will disagree that X is really worth 50 points (50 being a typical score for a ‚Äúnormal‚Äù word in many systems).

It stands for electronic moderation units. 

These comments are moderated mostly by emus, not humans... So, if you post frequently, especially short comments, they often get caught in an emu filter, probably as potential spam or bot behavior, and aren't released until or unless a human moderator catches it.

@Dave 
There is a solution to your issue for future reference, essentially based on the well known David Connell Technique. When working with multiple rebuses, if you want your puzzle to look ‚Äúperfect‚Äù at the end with all the correct entries and no single letter ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù answers, you need to leave one known non-rebus answer blank until the end. That way the music won‚Äôt suddenly appear when you are not ready. A variation of this occurs when you are solving with Autocheck. As I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôve noticed, in that setting if you have a rebus square filled with a single letter, it will be in blue and you can‚Äôt simply erase it. The trick is to go to that square, hit rebus, and enter an incorrect second letter, then (in iOS) hit rebus again, and the entry will now be in black with a line through it, and it can be erased. If you don‚Äôt use David‚Äôs technique and get the music, you‚Äôre done and have to clear the puzzle and start over.

I enjoy the constructor's notes because they give an insight into the mind(s) that created the puzzle. This one was interesting because the challenge, apparently, was less to fill the grid, than to find a way to trick a grid-filling program into doing something unusual. Purists may have a problem with this but as long as it's a tasty puzzle, I care how it got made.

Here's what I had to understand before I could solve:

1) There will be exactly two letters placed in every gray square.

2) When read in order -- either clockwise or counterclockwise -- around the grid, the letters will add up to complete gibberish.

3) But they WILL add up to a real word in the four clued sections!

4) You will know what letters to put in there from the crossing words -- some of them Acrosses and some of them Downs.

I LOVED THIS PUZZLE!!!  All rebus all the time -- and very tricky.

The hardest thing for me was to see what I was writing/had written in the tiny gray squares.  So tiny.  So gray.  Worse, my two letters blocked out what I could see of the numbers in the grid -- already challenging for me in a normal puzzle.  But I soldiered on.

Thought I'd have to Google CARELL; SUAREZ and LILAC -- and was thoroughly prepared to do so.  But I managed to finish without Googling anything.

Is it ridiculous to have that LILAC clue based on a "setting" in a kid's book from almost a century ago?  Yes, it's ridiculous.  Evidently I devoured all of the Nancy Drew canon by the time I was 6 or 7 (I was an early reader) and yet today I wouldn't know LILAC if I fell over it. But "biting" had to be ACERB (and if not ACERB then ACRID.)  Either way, the ending -AC at 9A in a "flowery" clue gave me LILAC.

A wonderfully challenging and stimulating puzzle that really engrossed me and that I enjoyed to the hilt.
